header.title: A Mandaean Book of Black Magic
header.category: Western Esotericism, Occultism, Mandaean Studies, Grimoire Tradition

central_thesis: E.S. Drower presents a translated and analyzed collection of Mandaean magical texts, identifying them as 'black magic' (haršia bišia) due to their Mandaean classification. The work elucidates the practical mechanics, ancient origins, and syncretic elements of these talismans and incantations, providing a unique window into Mandaean operative magic and its broader Middle Eastern folk magic context despite the corrupt nature of the source manuscripts.

structure_content.summary: Drower introduces the challenges of her research, noting the fragmented and corrupt nature of Mandaean manuscripts (MSS. D.C. 45 & 46). She categorizes the magic as 'black magic' (haršia bišia) and highlights its ancient origins, often drawing parallels to Sumerian and Jewish magical traditions, and noting the prevalence of Arabic texts transliterated into Mandaic script. She describes the typical setting of a Mandaean priest practicing magic in Baghdad bazaars.

The magical texts are broadly classified into groups based on their purpose: curative (including against the Evil Eye), inducing pregnancy or protecting the embryo, protection against enemies and demons, stopping children from weeping, assisting fowlers and fishermen, love-charms, and jealousy-spells. The texts often contain gibberish, invocations of angels, demons, genii, and magical figures resembling cuneiform or child-like drawings.

structure_content.chapter_title: I. Curative and Against the Evil Eye
structure_content.summary: This section details charms for healing various ailments, fever, and protection from the Evil Eye. Rituals include writing talismans to be melted in water for consumption, tying them to the body, or reading incantations over specific substances like saffron-dyed eggs. Angelic invocations are common, and the 'Great Life' is frequently named as the source of healing. Many texts are noted as corrupt or illegible by Drower.

structure_content.chapter_title: II. To Induce Pregnancy, or Protect the Embryo
structure_content.summary: These charms aim to promote fertility or safeguard the unborn child. They involve binding female liliths and male gods, invoking Mandaean life-spirits ('uthras) and specific angels (e.g., Nuriel, Sauriel, Tibiel). Practical applications include writing spells in a hollow basin for the woman to drink steeped sesame oil, or writing on gazelle-skin to be worn during labor. Corruption in these texts is frequently noted.

Charms in this category are designed to subjugate enemies, cause estrangement, or offer protection. Methods include invoking specific angels (e.g., Rufiel, Markiel, Gabriel), reading commands over bitter salt for placement in an enemy's house, or using pitch to bind and estrange. The illness or trouble is often personified as a demon, and Solomon is depicted as an exorcist.

structure_content.chapter_title: IV. For Children's Ailments and Crying
structure_content.summary: These spells address childhood issues like incessant crying, nightmares, and other infirmities. Some exhibit a nursery rhyme quality, invoking a 'Fish of Sleep' or Christian figures. Rituals involve writing charms to be worn on the neck (e.g., inserted into an onion of three knots), or for specific actions like inducing a child to suckle from its wet-nurse. The texts are often badly misspelt.

structure_content.chapter_title: V. Charms for Fowler and Fisherman
structure_content.summary: These charms are intended to aid fowlers and fishermen in catching game and fish. They involve invoking specific angels (e.g., Zarziel, Hudiel, Zaranaiel) to liberate birds and fishes into the practitioner's snare. Practical instructions include reciting charms over salt and mustard, tying them to the forearm, or writing them on silk for wearing or on the snare itself.

This section contains numerous spells for inducing love, passion, and subjugation between individuals, applicable to both sexes. Key invocations include Libat (Venus), angels of love, the 'Great Life', and celestial bodies (Sun, Moon, Seven Planets, Twelve Signs of the Zodiac). Rituals vary widely, from writing on specific materials and burying, to consuming charmed substances, or wearing talismans for magnetic attraction.

These charms focus on causing alienation, sundering relationships, and inflicting misfortune or repulsion. They invoke specific angels and deities (e.g., Bel, Nebo, Libat) to turn people away from each other. Practical instructions include writing spells on eggs to be buried at an enemy's gate, or smearing pitch on a door after incantation to estrange a couple. The texts often personify the target with animalistic features or apply harsh imagery.

key_concepts.definition: Mandaean term for 'evil magic' or 'black magic,' used by the Mandaeans themselves to categorize the spells in this collection.
Written charms, often incorporating magical figures, images, and texts, used as primary implements for various magical operations. These can be worn, consumed, buried, or applied to objects.
A common affliction in Mandaean belief, targeted by numerous curative and protective charms to avert its negative effects.
A Mandaean deity, identified with the planet Venus and the Babylonian Ishtar/Dilbat, frequently invoked in love and jealousy charms as the 'mistress of gods and men' to influence relationships.

key_concepts.term: N. son of N. (or N. daughter of N.)
key_concepts.definition: A standard placeholder in magical texts, signifying the name of the client or target, often including the mother's name for precise identification, as 'the parent's name in magic is always that of the mother'.

The primary method of activating charms, involving the calling upon various Mandaean angels, life-spirits ('uthras), and celestial entities (e.g., Seven Planets, Twelve Signs of the Zodiac) to perform specific magical tasks.

A key operative principle, exemplified by creating clay images (often from river-paths) to represent targets, or using specific animal parts (e.g., bitch's skin) or objects (e.g., horseshoes) for analogical influence.

practical_system.description: The Mandaean magical system described is an operative grimoire tradition heavily reliant on written talismans (charms or phylacteries) and oral incantations. It functions primarily through invocation and adjuration of specific angels, deities (like Libat), and sometimes demons. Ritual actions are concrete and often involve sympathetic magic, aiming to bind, separate, attract, heal, or harm. The magical efficacy is tied to the correct performance of these rituals, often requiring the use of specific natural materials and precise timing or placement.
tools: Paper, cotton strips, gazelle-skin, horseshoes, hollow basins (without engraving), skin of a bitch (as writing surfaces)
Spices, herbs, various other substances for ritual
rituals: Writing talismans on diverse materials (paper, cotton strips, gazelle-skin, horseshoes, hollow basins, skin of a bitch).
Melting written talismans in water or milk for the client to drink.
Burying talismans at specific locations (outer doors, under fires, at crossroads, under the head of sleepers).
Tying talismans to the body (right hand, neck, forearm) or to objects (snare, she-goat's legs).
Reading incantations over ritual substances (sesame oil, saffron-dyed eggs, pitch, salt, mustard) before consumption, smearing, or scattering.
Creating clay images (e.g., from river-paths) for sympathetic magic to represent individuals.
Smearing pitch on doors to cause estrangement.
Whispering charms with a bell to obscure understanding.

relevant_quotes.text: The magic of this book I have termed 'black', for the Mandeans themselves regard the book as haršia bišia, 'evil magic.'
A dictionary-maker, however, may neglect no text, however corrupt, and although the illiteracy of scribes has led me on many a googoose chase, the labour has been amply compensated.

For magic is a trade. Few of the magician's clients are literate enough to criticize what is written for them; indeed, only a minority are Mandæans, and Moslems, Jews, and Christians look upon incomprehensibility as part of the mystery of the spell.
In the name of the sundering angels! There shall be sundering of N. (woman) from N. (man). Sundered is Bel from Babylon, sundered Nebo from Borsippa, sundered is Nišra from Kaškar.
Write this talisman, melt it in water and give it to the fevered person to drink.
In the name of Libat (Venus), mistress of gods and men! He shall be brought into subjection, this man, N., neath the feet of N., woman...
Write this charm on gazelle-skin and tie it to the woman's neck when her labour begins.

critical_analysis.relevance: This book is profoundly relevant for scholars and practitioners of esotericism due to its unique focus on Mandaean magic, a tradition less documented than Western Grimoire traditions. Drower's meticulous translation of highly corrupt texts provides primary source material, shedding light on syncretic practices blending Mandaean, Sumerian, Jewish, and Arabic influences. It offers practical insights into operative folk magic, demonstrating how magical systems adapt and persist across cultural and linguistic boundaries, and highlighting the importance of 'black magic' in a Gnostic-influenced religion.
critical_analysis.target_audience: The primary audience includes academic researchers in Mandaean studies, comparative religion, and the history of magic. Practitioners of occultism, particularly those interested in grimoire traditions, folk magic, or the Middle Eastern esoteric currents, would find it valuable for its detailed operative instructions and philosophical underpinnings. Anthropologists studying religious practices and ethnographers of Iraqi and Iranian cultural traditions would also benefit.
